I.  THE ONGOING PROJECT 
1.  The  Board  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  the  Public–Private 
Partnership Support Project on 25 October 2012. The project supports the Government of Viet 
Nam  in  developing  bankable  and  commercially  viable  public–private  partnership  (PPP) 
initiatives, promoting a more conducive environment for PPP, and using PPP as a catalyst for 
broader  sector  reforms.  Under  the  project,  ADB  will  provide  funding  of  SDR13,171,000 
(equivalent to $20 million) for the establishment and operation of a project development facility 
(PDF) as a funding mechanism to support PPP project preparation activities, which will include 
the  preparation  of  prefeasibility  studies,  detailed  feasibility  studies,  and  bid  and  contract 
documentation. The loan agreement for the project was signed by ADB and the government on 
17 January 2013 and became effective on 28 May 2013.  
 
2.  The  Ministry  of  Planning  and  Investment  (MPI)  is  the  executing  agency.  The 
procurement process for the core team of consultants that will support MPI is currently being 
implemented.  The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  increased  private  sector  investment  in 
infrastructure. This will in turn improve the efficiency and quality of infrastructure services and 
accelerate Viet Nam’s economic growth. The outcome will be stronger government capacity to 
catalyze PPPs and infrastructure investments. The key outputs are an institutional mechanism 
for developing bankable PPP projects, a more robust PPP enabling framework, and stronger 
institutional capacity for PPP.  
    
II.  THE ADDITIONAL FINANCING 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Agence Française de Développement (AFD) has agreed to provide a cofinancing loan of 
€8 million (equivalent to $10 million) that will be used to fund the PDF. AFD and the government 
signed the loan agreement on 9 April 2013. The additional financing from AFD will be used to 
expand the scale of the PDF, and is consistent with project development objectives, government 
priorities, and ADB’s current country partnership strategy1. A cofinancing agreement between 
ADB and AFD now needs to be prepared, setting out the administration arrangements for the 
facility. 
 
B.  Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
4.  The aggregate impact and outcome of the project will not change as a consequence of 
the additional financing. The project outputs remain the same, although the additional financing 
from AFD will enable the pipeline of PPP projects to be processed by PDF will increase from 10 
to 15 by 2016. The loan funds from ADB and AFD (the cofinanciers’ loans) will be used to 
finance the following  activities  based  on  defined  ratios for  each  cost  category:2 (i) engage 
international consultants for the PDF technical team who will support the MPI in managing the 
PDF and (ii) engage consultants to undertake project preparation activities for potential PPP 
projects, including the preparation of prefeasibility studies and detailed feasibility studies, and 
provision of transaction advisory services. The estimated number of international consultant 
inputs for the PDF technical team will increase from 52 months to 90 months.  The consultant 
                                                
1 ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: Viet Nam, 2012–2015. Manila 
2 The cost allocation arrangement between ADB and AFD will be done in line with Option 3 of OM J6 (i.e., different 
ratios specified for each cost category) and will be as follows: (i) 63.5:36.5 for international consultants on the PDF 
technical team and (ii) 67.7:32.3 for project development costs (Appendixes 2 and 3).

2 
inputs for project development will be determined by the PDF technical team following project 
screening and selection. 
 
5.         ADB will partially administer the AFD funds and be responsible for the recruitment of 
consultants and the disbursement of the cofinanciers’ loans for the purposes detailed in para. 4. 
The selection, engagement, and services of these consultants will be in accordance with the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). For the purposes 
of the project, the disbursements from the AFD loan will be in accordance with ADB’s Loan 
Disbursement Handbook (2012, as amended from time to time). 
 
C.  Cofinancing 
 
6.  The proposed AFD cofinancing was initially part of the project concept, but at the time of 
ADB loan negotiations the government had not secured internal clearance to borrow from AFD. 
Therefore, AFD cofinancing was not included in the report and recommendation of the President 
for the project.3 AFD has completed negotiations with the government and signed an agreement 
for an €8 million loan on 9 April 2013 under its sovereign loan conditions. The AFD loan will fund 
the PDF, and it will be administered by ADB under a proposed cofinancing agreement on a joint 
basis. Interest on the AFD loan has been computed at 2.38% per annum as per standard AFD-
subsidized loan conditions (PS2).4 This cost will be directly borne by the government and will 
not  be  drawn  from  the  loan  proceeds.  AFD  will  provide  retroactive  financing  for  project 
development  expenses  already  incurred  by  the  Authorised  State  Agencies  or  People’s 
Committees subject to the latter following the prescribed procedure detailed in the procurement 
plan. The retroactive financing amount will not exceed €60,000 and will be for eligible expenses 
incurred  within  9  months  before  signing  of  the  loan  agreement  between  AFD  and  the 
government. The revised investment and financing plans are in Tables 1 and 2. 
 
Table 1: Revised Investment Plan  
($ million)

Republic of Viet Nam for the Public Private Partnership Support Project. Manila (project no. 44507-002, October 
2012). 
4  A category of subsidized AFD sovereign loans. Interest rate of AFD loan is Euribor +0.18% per annum, the 
equivalent fixed rate estimated based on the market conditions of October 17, 2012 was 2.38% per annum.

3 
AFD = Agence Française de Développement, PDF = project development facility. 
a  Includes taxes and duties of $2.1 million to be financed from Asian Development Bank (ADB) and AFD loan 
resources. Financing of taxes and duties from the ADB–AFD loan funds are justified because (i) it will not represent 
an excessive share of the project investment plan, (ii) the taxes and duties apply only to ADB- and AFD-financed 
expenditures, and (iii) the financing of taxes and duties is material and relevant to the success of the project. 
b  PDF operating costs include establishment costs of the government’s project management unit, staff salaries, 
office rental, utilities, supplies, transportation, and miscellaneous costs. 
c  PDF technical team costs consist of consultant fees over the first 3 years for consultants that will support the 
Ministry of Planning and Investment in managing the PDF. 
d Project development consists of consultant fees for the preparation of prefeasibility studies and detailed feasibility 
studies and the provision of transaction advisory services for PPP projects. 
e  Includes interest charges. Interest on the ADB loan has been computed at 1% per annum for the first 8 years as 
per standard Asian Development Fund loan guidelines.  Interest on the AFD loan has been computed at 2.38% per 
annum as per standard AFD PS2 loan conditions. This cost will be directly borne by the Government of Viet Nam 
and will not be drawn from the loan proceeds. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

a ADB’s disbursement percentages are presented in Attachment to Schedule 3 of ADB’s loan agreement and this 
  table will be updated to reflect the additional financing (Appendix 3).  The ADB and AFD disbursement percentages 
will be effective upon signing of the cofinancing agreement. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
7.  ADB has undertaken due diligence of the project for the additional financing to confirm 
the details of the AFD loan agreement. The MPI prepared feasibility studies for both the ADB 
and AFD loans. ADB completed a mission to Viet Nam from 10–12 December 2012, and held 
discussions with the MPI and AFD on the status of feasibility studies and loan negotiations. ADB 
has received a copy of the signed loan agreement between the government and AFD.   
 
8.  There is no change to the implementation arrangements for the project. The MPI will be 
the executing agency in collaboration with the PPP task force and other government ministries 
and agencies involved in PPP. The task force, chaired by the MPI and comprising the Ministry 
of Finance, Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Industry and Trade, Ministry of Transport, Ministry of 
Construction, State Bank of Viet Nam, and other relevant agencies, was established in mid-
January 2011 to provide overall guidance to the government’s PPP piloting initiative. The task 
force is being restructured to allow more senior representation of the ministries, which will 
enable it to function more effectively as an inter-ministerial coordination body for PPP. The task 
force will have high-level oversight of the PDF and will be the mechanism for coordination of line 
ministries on the use of the PDF. A dedicated project management unit will be established with 
staff assigned from the PPP office of the MPI for day-to-day management of the PDF under the 
project. The unit will be supported by a team of national and international experts on PPP who 
will be funded by the project. The estimated completion date continues to be June 2018.

4 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
 
9.  The President recommends that the Board approve ADB administering the loan not 
exceeding the equivalent of €8.0 million to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for additional 
financing  of  the  Public–Private  Partnership  Support  Project,  to  be  provided  by  Agence 
Française de Développement.
